citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection it was determined that the facility does not have a current program of veterinary care or an actual
attending veterinarian. The previous attending veterinarian has moved practice and is no longer available, and there has
been no replacement found for the past several months. There is no current program of veterinary care documenting any
formal arrangements with an attending veterinarian or the regularly scheduled visits for the regulated animals.
The lack of an attending veterinarian and documentation of the program of vet care can cause the lack of proper
preventive care being given in a timely manner and the lack of veterinary care for any medical issues that arise.
Each dealer and exhibitor shall employ an attending veterinarian under formal arrangements. In the case of a part-time
attending veterinarian or consultant arrangements, the formal arrangements shall include a written program of veterinary
care and regularly scheduled visits to the premises of the dealer or exhibitor
To be corrected by: January 19, 2025

The current inventory at the facility is missing the birds used for exhibit purposes.
Complete documentation of the regulated animals is needed for proper management and traceability of the animals.
Every dealer other than operators of auction sales and brokers to whom animals are consigned, and exhibitor shall make,
keep, and maintain records or forms which fully and correctly disclose the following information concerning animals other
than dogs and cats, purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in his or her possession or under
his or her control, or which is transported, sold, euthanized, or otherwise disposed of by that dealer or exhibitor. The
records shall include any offspring born or hatched of any animal while in his or her possession or under his or her
control, to the extent that any identification or counting of offspring can be carried out without unduly disturbing nesting or
rearing activities.
To be corrected by: January 19, 2025

There is no written documentation of an emergency plan for the facility for their regulated animals.
The lack of documentation and planning for an emergency situation for the licensee and staff could cause a lack of timely
reaction time to capture, remove, transport or care for animals at the facility. The lack of preparedness could cause
unnecessary stress or harm to the regulated animals in a situation where timely action and emergency contacts may be
required.
Dealers, exhibitors, intermediate handlers, and carriers must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to
provide for the humane handling, treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an
emergency or disaster (one which could reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and
well-being of the animals in their possession).
To be corrected by: January 19, 2025

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
There is no written documentation of enrichment for the regulated birds at the facility. There are not enough perching
areas in the kestrel enclosure to provide some other areas to move within the primary enclosure. The current perch
available is at an angle that does not allow for a flat stable perching point that can cause stress on the legs without the
bird having any other options for perching.
The lack of enrichment options for captive birds can cause regulated animals to become stressed or engage in harmful
physical or psychological behaviors due to boredom or other health issues. There should be some documentation of
enrichment options that are species specific due to their natural habits and needs, and some efforts to provide such items
in their primary enclosures or exercise areas.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. This plan must be made
available to APHIS upon request.
To be corrected by: January 19. 2025

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is a buildup of bird droppings under the perches of the Kestrel and Screech Owl enclosures of approximately 3 to 4
inches in height. While the facility tries to clean the enclosures weekly, these two enclosures appear to have been allowed
to accumulate waste for at least 3-4 weeks.
The lack of proper cleaning and sanitization can cause a buildup of waste and debris that can become a disease hazard
for the regulated animal that can not move away from the area to distance itself from the waste or vermin and disease
attracted to it.
Primary enclosures and food and water receptacles for birds must be sanitized as often as necessary to prevent
accumulation of dirt, debris, food waste, excreta, and other disease hazards.
To be corrected by: December 23, 2024
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with licensee.
